name: Idosawa
description:
This is a short canyon - the lower waterfalls are visible near the parking on approach to Unazawa Tani canyon. Parking is available in the layby immediately after the corner where the falls become visible. (This is a space before the larger parking area for Unazawa Tani) [Parking is free]

Approach

There is an 8m artificial fall (low head dam) on the Unazawa stream just upstream of the point where Idosawa joins. Cross the stream above these falls. A steep trail goes up the back (seemingly in a direction away from Idosawa.) Follow this trail and it eventually cuts back across. The trail drops in the stream and then climbs back up out on the river left side. The trail disappears at times, but it is possible to keep traversing across the river left side of the stream until you want to enter the water (although the bank can be steep and loose - footing precarious and trees unreliable hand holds)

Descent

Careful at the section marked 'debris' There are loads of fallen trees - not particularly stable. With some downclimbing (slippery!) the final part can be slid - although the pool is only about 4.5ft deep.


27Jun17 - amendments, following a second descent

1. Slide below fallen debris is good to go with some caution and proper technique

2. First rappel at the cave section, marked 'Jump?' on topo, is good to go as a jump. The further you jump out, the shallower it gets, but the whole pool is reasonably safe to land in with good technique.

3. The penultimate rappel pitch, marked 'No Jump!' on topo, is good to go as a jump. On the first descent, with the time pressure on, and nearing the end, we were overly cautious. This jump was no problem; pool is around 6-6.5ft deep all over.

Exit

You come out into the Unazawa stream. The easiest way to return to the car is to scramble back up towards the artificial falls. A trail climbs upwards near here - there is a rope handrail in place.

Red tape

None.

Beta sites

No other beta available (?)

Trip reports and media

Background

Ascended and descend by shower climbing groups in the past. Lower section used to be equipped with pitons that have since been removed. Various parties have expressed an interest / intention in bolting the canyon.
